When a beam of light passes through a medium, it bends or refracts. The amount of bending depends on the refractive index of the medium.
Different colors of light have different wavelengths and are refracted by different amounts. Generally, shorter wavelengths (like violet) are refracted more than longer wavelengths (like red).
The refractive index \( n \) of a material is defined as the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum \( c \) to the speed of light in the medium \( v \), i.e., \( n = \frac{c}{v} \).
A higher refractive index means the light travels slower in the material.
